content.webTitle: Whitehall oblivious to effects of cuts, says National Audit Office head

fields.headline: Whitehall oblivious to effects of cuts, says National Audit Office head
fields.bodyText: Whitehall ministers are carrying out dramatic cuts to public spending without grasping the impact they are having on the ground, the head of Britain’s spending watchdog has said. Sir Amyas Morse, who leads the National Audit Office, accused ministers of irresponsible decision-making. “If you’re going to do radical surgery it would be nice if you knew where the heart was,” he said in an interview with the Financial Times. “You’re slightly more likely not to stick a knife in it by mistake.” Morse, who reports directly to parliament rather than to a minister, warned that officials lack the information or overview to judge whether cuts were leading to improvements in efficiency or simply stripping back services. Under David Cameron’s leadership, an “optimism bias” had encouraged ministers to pursue projects in which they deeply believed — such as the NHS reforms — without fully debating the potential risks, Morse added. He pointed to local government cuts, which have led to a major reduction in the funding of social care and intensified the pressure on the NHS. “Now if you’re going to go through much deeper, more profound organisational cuts ... you need to understand what you’re doing better than that,” he said. Speaking two days before George Osborne announces his his sixth budget, Morse said ministers were being “more ‘executive’ in style”. “I’m not saying that’s wrong, but it’s a feature,” he said. “That means that as a civil servant, you’re faced with someone who’s saying ‘this is what I strongly believe we should do here’”. Where there are problems or deficiencies with policies, civil servants had sometimes been reluctant to address them, he added. “What I observed is something that I will collectively describe as the feather game. Because if you keep blowing the feather hopefully it will land on someone else,” he said. He added that civil servants should not adopt the attitude that they are not responsible for what happens in local government. While this reluctance by departments to add to their responsibilities was understandable at one level, “you’d like to feel that they’d be steering towards the sound of gunfire, rather than steering away from it”, he said. Morse said the Treasury had initially been disinclined to scrutinise whether the severance payments offered to departing public sector staff were suitable. “They were very much not wanting to agree to do that,” he said. “And although they have now agreed to do it, they didn’t want to have the responsibility for picking up patterns and being a bit of a detector of things that might be going wrong.”
